passage_list.text: When I showed up at Rangina’s house, there were no guards outside anymore, and her government-issued armored SUV was gone from the driveway. When the Taliban had taken it, they’d assured her she would be safe. But she was getting ready to evacuate; there was only a week remaining until August 31, the deadline for the troops to leave, and she and Abdullah had decided to take Zara and get out.

The day before, Rangina had been invited to a meeting at the ministry with members of the Taliban’s education commission. Schools were closed since the collapse of the republic, but Rangina had wondered if they might ask her to continue in a temporary capacity, like Waheed Majrooh, the minister of public health, who’d remained and helped keep the hospitals running through the violence at the airport. Rangina arrived with her deputy to find several older men in turbans sitting in her office. They were formal but polite; one turned out to be from a village in Kandahar next to her father’s. Together, they went to speak to the ministry’s senior staff. After thanking God for their victory, one of the Taliban officials gave a speech about placing Islam at the center of a new curriculum—now their fundamentalist vision would shape the next generation of Afghan children.

Afterward, the officials served her melon in the office. She wanted to know whether girls would be denied higher education as they were in the 1990s. The Taliban assured her that they would be allowed to study past sixth grade, but only after a system was worked out to keep men and women separate, in accordance with religious law.

“I don’t know if their definition of Shariah has changed from twenty years ago or if it’s the same Shariah—that’s the big question,” Rangina told me. “Shariah is not a book that you can pick up and say, ‘Here’s Shariah.’ It’s history and laws and regulations over 1,400 years, and it’s open to interpretation.”

The officials told her she no longer had a job at the ministry, but they asked her to stay in Afghanistan. They suggested she could help them by speaking to the media and telling the world they weren’t the monsters they were made out to be. Rangina was offended. “They just want me as their female spokesperson,” she said.

As a former minister and U.S. citizen, Rangina had been prioritized for evacuation. As we talked, her phone rang, and she answered it. It was a marine, calling from the military base in Qatar. “If we can help you out, would you be willing to work with us to get through a gate in HKIA and get put on an airplane?”

The next day, her deputy, Attaullah Wahidyar, drove them in a truck to Glory Gate, with Zara sitting quietly beside her and Abdullah in the back seat. Rangina was racked with guilt over leaving; maybe if she stayed, the Taliban would be willing to listen to her. Wahidyar was certain she was making the right decision. “They would have used her,” he told me later. “You can’t say no to a Talib with a gun.”

In the back of the pickup speeding toward the airport, Rangina wept as she remembered another journey she’d taken as a scared child more than thirty years ago. In the middle of the night, her father had taken the family and fled the communists in a truck like this one, and they’d become refugees. But now the little girl in the back seat was her own daughter, and she was sitting in her father’s place. And Ghulam Haider was dead, murdered, a martyr for the lost republic and the country she was leaving behind.

A few days after the evacuation ended, I passed by the office of Etilaat-e Roz and was surprised to find Zaki still there. A couple of weeks earlier, he’d told me that he and his staff had decided to leave while they still had a chance to get out. But they hadn’t been able to get through the crowds at the airport. Zaki had been offered a place on our Sayara convoy, but he wasn’t willing to go without his colleagues.

The Qataris, who were helping the Taliban get the airport running again, were still flying out some evacuees, so Zaki was hopeful that they could leave as a group in the coming days. A few of Zaki’s journalists were sitting around the office, looking depressed. They told me they hadn’t been out reporting yet; they were afraid of the Taliban on the street. I tried to reassure them by recounting how Mujahed, the spokesman, had given me a letter of permission and that I’d been able to keep working, even interview Taliban officials.

questions.question: What is the main reason Rangina is preparing to evacuate?

options.A: She no longer has a government-issued armored SUV.
options.B: The Taliban assured her she would be safe.
options.C: The deadline for the troops to leave is approaching.
options.D: She wants to avoid speaking to the media.

questions.explanation: The passage states that Rangina is preparing to evacuate because there is only a week remaining until August 31, the deadline for the troops to leave.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Focus on the key details that directly answer the question, avoiding distractors that are mentioned but not central to the main idea.

questions.question: As used in the passage, what does the word 'fundamentalist' most nearly mean?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'fundamentalist' refers to a strict adherence to traditional religious principles, which aligns with the idea of being radical.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use context clues to infer the meaning of unfamiliar words, especially when they describe ideologies or beliefs.

questions.question: What can be inferred about the Taliban's stance on education for girls?

options.A: They are fully supportive of girls' education without restrictions.
options.B: They plan to allow girls to study past sixth grade under certain conditions.
options.C: They are opposed to any form of education for girls.
options.D: They have not yet decided on a policy for girls' education.

questions.explanation: The passage indicates that the Taliban assured Rangina that girls would be allowed to study past sixth grade, but only after a system was worked out to keep men and women separate.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Look for implicit information that is not directly stated but can be logically inferred from the text.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Rangina's statement about Shariah?

options.A: To criticize the Taliban's interpretation of Shariah.
options.B: To explain the complexity and variability of Shariah.
options.C: To advocate for a stricter interpretation of Shariah.
options.D: To express her personal beliefs about Shariah.

questions.explanation: Rangina's statement emphasizes that Shariah is not a fixed set of rules but rather a complex system open to interpretation over 1,400 years.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Pay attention to the author's or character's intent when analyzing statements or quotes in the text.

questions.question: Which choice best describes Rangina's reaction to the Taliban's suggestion that she speak to the media?

options.A: She was flattered and agreed immediately.
options.B: She was offended and felt they were using her.
options.C: She was indifferent and ignored the suggestion.
options.D: She was confused and asked for clarification.

questions.explanation: Rangina was offended by the Taliban's suggestion, as she believed they wanted to use her as a female spokesperson.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze the character's emotional response and the reasons behind it to understand their perspective.

questions.question: Which piece of evidence best supports the idea that Rangina was prioritized for evacuation?

options.A: Her government-issued armored SUV was gone from the driveway.
options.B: She was a former minister and a U.S. citizen.
options.C: She had a meeting with the Taliban’s education commission.
options.D: Her deputy drove them in a truck to Glory Gate.

questions.explanation: The passage explicitly states that Rangina was prioritized for evacuation because she was a former minister and a U.S. citizen.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Identify direct textual evidence that supports the main idea or specific claims in the passage.

questions.question: How does Wahidyar's statement, 'You can’t say no to a Talib with a gun,' relate to Rangina's decision to evacuate?

options.A: It suggests that Rangina had no choice but to leave.
options.B: It implies that Rangina could have negotiated with the Taliban.
options.C: It indicates that Rangina was in physical danger.
options.D: It shows that Wahidyar supported the Taliban's actions.

questions.explanation: Wahidyar's statement underscores the lack of autonomy and the coercive power of the Taliban, reinforcing Rangina's decision to evacuate.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Analyze how different parts of the text connect to support or explain a character's actions or decisions.

questions.question: What can be inferred about Rangina's emotional state as she travels to the airport?

options.A: She is excited to start a new life abroad.
options.B: She is nostalgic and grieving for her lost country.
options.C: She is angry at the Taliban for forcing her to leave.
options.D: She is indifferent to the events happening around her.

questions.explanation: Rangina weeps and reflects on her past as a refugee, indicating a sense of nostalgia and grief for the country she is leaving behind.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use descriptive language and emotional cues in the text to infer a character's feelings or state of mind.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the author's description of Zaki's situation?

options.A: To highlight the challenges faced by journalists under the Taliban.
options.B: To criticize Zaki's decision to stay in Afghanistan.
options.C: To emphasize the success of the evacuation efforts.
options.D: To provide a personal anecdote about the author's experience.

questions.explanation: The description of Zaki's situation illustrates the difficulties and dangers journalists face under the Taliban regime.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Consider the broader context and implications of specific events or situations described in the text.

questions.question: Which choice best maintains the grammatical and logical coherence of the following sentence? 'The Qataris, who were helping the Taliban get the airport running again, were still flying out some evacuees, so Zaki was hopeful that they could leave as a group in the coming days.'

options.B: The Qataris, who were helping the Taliban get the airport running again, were still flying out some evacuees; so Zaki was hopeful that they could leave as a group in the coming days.
options.C: The Qataris, who were helping the Taliban get the airport running again, were still flying out some evacuees, Zaki was hopeful that they could leave as a group in the coming days.
options.D: The Qataris, who were helping the Taliban get the airport running again, were still flying out some evacuees. So Zaki was hopeful that they could leave as a group in the coming days.

questions.explanation: The original sentence is grammatically correct and logically coherent, with a clear cause-and-effect relationship.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Ensure that sentences maintain proper grammatical structure and logical flow, especially when dealing with complex ideas.

scoring_guidelines.700_level_performance: Students scoring at this level show strong comprehension and reasoning skills but may struggle with higher-level analysis and synthesis.

explanation_summary.hard_questions: Hard questions test advanced analytical and reasoning skills, often requiring students to infer meaning or analyze complex text structures.
explanation_summary.medium_questions: Medium questions assess comprehension and vocabulary in context, with a focus on understanding main ideas and details.
